title: Feeding-induced rearrangement of green leaf volatiles reduces moth oviposition
abstract: The ability to decrypt volatile plant signals is essential if herbivorous insects are to optimize their choice of host plants for their offspring. Green leaf volatiles (GLVs) constitute a widespread group of defensive plant volatiles that convey a herbivory-specific message via their isomeric composition: feeding of the tobacco hornworm <italic>Manduca sexta</italic> converts (<italic>Z</italic>)-3- to (<italic>E</italic>)-2-GLVs thereby attracting predatory insects. Here we show that this isomer-coded message is monitored by ovipositing <italic>M. sexta</italic> females. We detected the isomeric shift in the host plant <italic>Datura wrightii</italic> and performed functional imaging in the primary olfactory center of <italic>M. sexta</italic> females with GLV structural isomers. We identified two isomer-specific regions responding to either (<italic>Z</italic>)-3- or (<italic>E</italic>)-2-hexenyl acetate. Field experiments demonstrated that ovipositing <italic>Manduca</italic> moths preferred (<italic>Z</italic>)-3-perfumed <italic>D. wrightii</italic> over (<italic>E</italic>)-2-perfumed plants. These results show that (<italic>E</italic>)-2-GLVs and/or specific (<italic>Z</italic>)-3/(<italic>E</italic>)-2-ratios provide information regarding host plant attack by conspecifics that ovipositing hawkmoths use for host plant selection.
